metadata.case_name: Brij Bhushan v. Chief Commissioner of Delhi
metadata.case_number: Original Jurisdiction Petition No. XXIX of 1950

facts.text: Application under Article 32 of the Constitution for writs of certiorari and prohibition against the Chief Commissioner of Delhi to examine legality and quash order regarding Organizer, an English weekly of Delhi.
First petitioner Shri Brij Bhushan is printer and publisher of Organizer; second petitioner Shri K.R. Halkani is editor.

On 2nd March 1950, Chief Commissioner of Delhi, in exercise of powers under Section 7(1)(c) of East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 (extended to Delhi Province), issued order requiring petitioners to submit for scrutiny before publication all communal matter and news and views about Pakistan including photographs and cartoons (other than from official sources or specified news agencies) to Provincial Press Officer.

Order recites that Chief Commissioner satisfied Organizer publishing highly objectionable matter constituting threat to public law and order, and action necessary to prevent or combat activities prejudicial to public safety or maintenance of public order.

East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 passed to provide special measures to ensure public safety and maintenance of public order; enacted under Section 100 Govt of India Act 1935 read with Entry 1 List II Seventh Schedule (public order).
Delhi Province notified as dangerously disturbed area under Section 20 of the Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether Section 7(1)(c) of East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 infringes fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a) and is not justified as restriction under Article 19(2).

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 7(1)(c) authorises imposition of pre-censorship on journal, a restriction on liberty of press (essential part of freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a)) not justified under Article 19(2) as it does not relate to matters which undermine security of or tend to overthrow the State.

respondent_arguments.text: Section 7(1)(c) valid as necessary for preventing or combating activities prejudicial to public safety or maintenance of public order; confined to particular subject/class of subjects connected with public safety/public order.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 7(1)(c) East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949; Article 19(2)

court_reasoning.text: Imposition of pre-censorship is restriction on liberty of press, essential part of Article 19(1)(a); liberty of press consists in no previous restraints on publications.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restriction not falling within Article 19(2) reservation.

court_reasoning.text: Decision follows reasoning in Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras (Petition No. XVI of 1950); Section 7(1)(c) unconstitutional.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Same considerations as in prior case conclude present one.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent (Fazl Ali J.): Section 7(1)(c) confined to matters relating to public safety/maintenance of public order; public safety equivalent to security of State; Act for special measures in grave situations affecting State security; saved by Article 19(2) as public disorder/disturbance of tranquillity undermines security of State.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Public order and public safety allied; Act's dominant purpose preservation of public safety in special situations.

holdings.text: Section 7(1)(c) of East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 does not fall within permissible restrictions under Article 19(2); impugned order quashed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Romesh Thappar v. The State of Madras
precedents_cited.citation: Petition No. XVI of 1950, supra p. 594
precedents_cited.relevance: Same considerations on Article 19(1)(a) and (2) conclude present case.

precedents_cited.case_name: Niharendu Dutt Majumdar v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Sedition gist is public disorder or likelihood thereof (dissent).

precedents_cited.case_name: King Emperor v. Sadashiv Narayan Bhalerao
precedents_cited.relevance: Sedition under IPC s.124A not requiring incitement to disorder (dissent).

precedents_cited.case_name: Rex v. Governor of Wormwood Scrubbs Prison
precedents_cited.relevance: Public safety includes prevention of internal disorder (dissent).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental right to freedom of speech; restrictions permitted; writ jurisdiction; definition of State.

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorises pre-publication scrutiny for public safety/public order; declaration of disturbed areas.

outcome.summary: Petition allowed; impugned order of Chief Commissioner dated 2nd March 1950 quashed as Section 7(1)(c) violates Article 19(1)(a) not saved by Article 19(2), following Romesh Thappar case. (Fazl Ali J. dissenting).

key_quotes.text: "the liberty of the press consists in laying no previous restraint upon publications, and not in freedom from censure for criminal matter when published."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines liberty of press under Article 19(1)(a); basis for holding pre-censorship invalid.

key_quotes.text: "As this question turns on considerations which are essentially the same as those on which our decision in Petition No. XVI of 1950 was based, our judgment in that case concludes the present case also."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Majority relies on Romesh Thappar to strike down section.

key_quotes.text: "public safety is, as we have seen, equivalent to security of the State".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissenting view linking public safety/public order to Article 19(2) protection.
